Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: Quantitative Analysis and Design of Control Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop the scientific foundation for the quantitative analysis and design of control networks. Control networks are wireless substrates for industrial automation control, such as the WirelessHART and Honeywell's OneWireless, and have fundamental differences over their sensor network counterparts as they also include actuation and the physical dynamics. The approach of the project focuses on understanding cross-cutting interfaces between computing systems, control systems, sensor networks, and wireless communications using time-triggered architectures.

The intellectual merit of this research is based on using time-triggered communication and computation as a unifying abstraction for understanding control networks. Time-triggered architectures enable the natural integration of communication, computation, and physical aspects of control networks as switched control systems. The time-triggered abstraction will serve for addressing the following interrelated themes: Optimal Schedules via Quantitative Automata, Quantitative Analysis and Design of Control Networks: Wireless Protocols for Optimal Control: Quantitative Trust Management for Control Networks.

Various components of this research will be integrated into the PIs' RAVEN control network which is compatible with both WirelessHART and OneWireless specifications. This provides a direct path for this proposal to have immediate industrial impact. In order to increase the broader impact of this project, this project will launch the creation of a Masters' program in Embedded Systems, one of the first in the nation. The principle that guides the curriculum development of this novel program is a unified systems view of computing, communication, and control systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent years have witnessed the availability of extremely powerful yet inexpensive computing, the explosion of communication networks, and revolutions in sensor and actuator technology. These advances have found their way inside many physical systems such as cars, chemical processes and manufacturing systems, resulting in the so-called cyber-physical systems (CPS) which merge physical processes with information systems. Despite this tremendous promise, the inherent heterogeneity of cyber-physical systems has been extremely challenging as most principled design approaches completely ignore cross-cutting constraints. 


Our project was inspired by the recent development of wireless substrates for industrial automation control, such as ISA 100.11a - a wireless communication standard specifically designed to address the needs of the control industry for reliable and secure wireless communication in real world industrial plant applications. Such wireless control networks have fundamental differences over their sensor network counterparts as they also include actuation and, perhaps more importantly, the physical dynamics of the system(s) being controlled is fundamental in closing the feedback loop. Furthermore, deploying control networks for controlling physical systems dramatically raises the requirements on safety, performance, reliability, security for the integrated cyber-physical system.


In our work we developed the scientific foundation for the quantitative analysis and design of control networks. Our approach exploited the cross-cutting interfaces between computing systems, control systems, sensor networks, and wireless communications. Architecturally we committed to time-triggered communication and computation for real-time control, which is a de-facto standard in modern industrial automation and manufacturing systems. We exploited a major technical advantage of time triggered control/communication methods enabling precise semantics for real-time computing/communication, thus paving for the natural integration of communication, computation, and physical aspects of control networks in the mathematical framework of switched control systems. 


Specifically, the intellectual outcomes of the project include: 
- A method for quantitative modeling and and analysis of wireless control networks. 

- Based on the above model, optimal communication/computation scheduling in wireless control networks

- A simple, low-overhead method for decentralized control of industrial process control and automation systems 

- Embedded Virtual Machine architecture for fault-tolerant control over multi-hop wireless control networks

- Opportunistic policies for compositional scheduling of control and communication in wireless control networks. 

Various components of our research were integrated in our design of open communications tack compatible with ISA100.11a. With support from our industrial partners, such as Honeywell, we illustrated their use on several case studies, including decentralized control of distillation columns and mineral floatation control in the Garpenberg mine Boliden, in Sweden. 


This project facilitated launching of the PRECISE research center at the University of Pennsylvania, which has a longstanding commitment to addressing cross-cutting challenges on the interfaces between control, computation, and communication. Furthermore, outcomes of our educational effort include development of the first in the nation Masters’ program in Embedded Systems (EMBS) at the University of Pennsylvania, which is creating a new generation of scientists and engineers that are equally fluent in computing and physical systems.
